title: The huge corporate finance story lurking behind Greensill's collapse
text:
Don't miss on Thursday: Sujeet Indap talks about his newly published book The Caesars Palace Coup and the distressed debt industry with leading investors and advisers. Details and sign up here.

Welcome to Due Diligence, your briefing on dealmaking, private equity and corporate finance from the Financial Times. Want to receive DD in your inbox? Sign up here. Get in touch with us anytime: Due.Diligence@ft.com.  

From Greensill to Gupta

Lex Greensill has been a recurring character in this newsletter for a long time. Now the Australian financier is at the centre of Britain's biggest lobbying scandal in a generation.

While the political fallout from Greensill Capital's rise and fall is now dominating British newspaper front pages, there is a bigger corporate finance story lurking in the background that is only just getting going: Sanjeev Gupta.

The 49-year-old trader-turned-industrialist has also proved himself a savvy political operator, beguiling politicians across the spectrum with his vision of a greener steel industry.

Gupta has in a few short years stitched together a sprawling metals-to-banking conglomerate, through an acquisition spree of steel plants and other ageing industrial assets, which has seen his so-called GFG Alliance hit $20bn in annual revenues.

And much of the financial firepower underpinning that rise came from the now-collapsed Greensill Capital, which disclosed in court last month that it had an eye-watering $5bn of debt exposure to Gupta's businesses.

The so-called saviour of steel has more than just the collapse of his main lender to contend with.

A recent run of Financial Times investigations have shone an uncomfortable light on Liberty Commodities, the trading firm the Indian-born businessman says he established from a Cambridge university dorm room in 1992.

The company advertises itself as “one of the leading independent non-ferrous traders”, with annual turnover of more than $6bn. But the FT revealed earlier this month that some of the invoices it has raised financing against appear to be dubious.

Companies named on the paperwork deny doing business with Liberty, raising suspicions of fraud. In a letter to the FT expressing his disappointment with the article, Gupta said he refuted “any suggestion of wrongdoing”.

Now the FT has revealed just how much of Liberty Commodities' revenue has at times relied on a loose network of related companies, which insiders call the “Friends of Sanjeev”.

While ostensibly independent, employees of the GFG Alliance were often deeply involved in their administration, at times co-ordinating audits, signing loan documents on their behalf and even helping set up corporate websites.

The FT has been able to piece together the ways these seemingly independent entities are interwoven with one another — through a revolving door of shareholders and directors — using public records, together with interviews with people directly involved in many of the transactions.

Go deeper with DD's Rob Smith and the FT's Cynthia O'Murchu and Michael Pooler here.

The incoming Credit Suisse chair opens up over lunch 

Lunches with the FT can be notoriously riotous affairs. 

Nigel Farage shared six pints of ale, a bottle of wine and two glasses of port in 2016, while Richard Desmond once nonchalantly added a £580 bottle of château Palmer to the FT's tab.

Not so with António Horta-Osório, the outgoing Lloyds Bank boss and incoming Credit Suisse chair. 

The tennis fanatic has been on something of a fitness drive throughout lockdown, skipping breakfast and taking early morning 5km runs four times a week. In the process, he lost 3kg.

During his recent lunch with the FT's Patrick Jenkins, the Portuguese banker avoided alcohol and pudding, settling instead for dressed crab, Dover sole and his trademark green tea.

Horta-Osório knows more than most about the importance of staying physically and mentally healthy when taking on high-octane jobs. Within months of being parachuted into the part-nationalised Lloyds in 2011, he was diagnosed with stress-related exhaustion and sent to the Priory clinic to recover.

“The reason why I really stopped sleeping is because I could see that the bank could die,” the 57-year-old told the FT. “I could not share this with anyone. I took it really to heart as my responsibility to save it.”

Horta-Osório faces an equally daunting challenge as he joins Credit Suisse next week. 

The Swiss lender has been pummeled by twin crises surrounding Greensill Capital and Archegos Capital Management in recent months. These have come on the back of a series of calamities stretching back over several years. 

Last week Credit Suisse went cap in hand to its shareholders, seeking to raise $1.9bn to help bolster its balance sheet.

It is fair to say the bank's shareholders are not overjoyed with its recent escapades. Several told the FT this week that they planned to vote against Andreas Gottschling, the Credit Suisse board member in charge of risk oversight, at the group's AGM on Friday.

Horta-Osório's abstinence may well be tested in the months ahead.

The revolving door and Jones Day

When it came to Donald Trump's presidency and big law, Kirkland & Ellis was most often seen as the law firm with the closest ties to the US president. That was largely thanks to alumni such as Bill Barr, who served as Trump's attorney-general. 

But when it comes to enduring links to the Trump movement and Republican party politics, Jones Day is the firm to watch. 

Founded over a century ago in Cleveland, Ohio, Jones Day once made its name representing businesses in the industrial Midwest, including Standard Oil. 

But in recent decades, it has developed into a powerhouse in Washington, where its prominence is symbolised by the proximity of its office to the US Capitol.  

However, its relationship with those running the US reached new heights during the Trump presidency. 

The firm earned more than $25m in fees from the Trump campaign and funnelled more lawyers into positions in the administration than any other. The list included Don McGahn, Trump's first White House counsel. 

Now those lawyers are flocking back to the firm. But its closeness to the former president and by extension, the far-right movement in the US, has rattled some within its ranks. 

Jones Day is notoriously secretive, even by the standards of its big law rivals. Insiders call its compensation system a “black box” and managing partner Stephen Brogan has ruled the roost for almost two decades with unusually broad discretion to control its operations. 

Go deeper with this look at the firm, which employs about 2,500 lawyers and makes over $2bn in revenue annually, by the FT's Kate Beioley and DD's Arash Massoudi. 

Job moves

  • Private equity firm Searchlight Capital Partners has appointed Ajit Pai, former chair of the US Federal Communications Commission, as a partner.

  • Bernd Osterloh, the head of Volkswagen's works council, which represents most of the manufacturer's 300,000 workers in Germany, is leaving the post to become head of human resources at truck-subsidiary Traton, and will be replaced by his deputy Daniela Cavallo. His resignation was greeted with silent relief by VW's top brass. Read why here. 

  • Blackstone has hired former LeumiTech chief Yifat Oron, as a senior managing director and head of the firm's new office in Tel Aviv. She was previously the chief executive of an Israeli tech banking platform and before that a partner at a venture capital firm.
